faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Everything you need to know about FytZone pricing

q1.question: Can I change my plan at any time?
q1.answer: Yes, you can upgrade or downgrade your plan at any time. Changes take effect immediately and we'll prorate any charges.

q2.question: Is there a free trial for paid plans?
q2.answer: Yes! All paid plans come with a 14-day free trial. No credit card required to start.

q3.question: What happens if I exceed my plan limits?
q3.answer: We'll notify you when you're approaching your limits. You can upgrade your plan or wait for the next billing cycle.

q4.question: Do you offer discounts for annual billing?
q4.answer: Yes, we offer 2 months free when you pay annually. Contact us for custom enterprise pricing.

privacy.title: Privacy &
privacy.description: Your data privacy and security are our top priorities. Learn how we protect your information.
privacy.mainDescription: We use advanced encryption and security measures to ensure your images and personal data remain completely private and secure.

technicalSecurity.title: Technical Security
technicalSecurity.content:
All images are encrypted using AES-256 encryption before upload and remain encrypted during processing.

Your data is stored in SOC 2 Type II certified data centers with multiple layers of security.

All data transmission uses TLS 1.3 encryption to protect against interception.

Our systems are designed so that only you can access your unencrypted data.

encryption.description: All images are encrypted using AES-256 encryption before upload and remain encrypted during processing.

transmission.title: Secure Transmission
transmission.description: All data transmission uses TLS 1.3 encryption to protect against interception.

access.title: Zero-Knowledge Access
access.description: Our systems are designed so that only you can access your unencrypted data.

compliance.title: GDPR & KVKK Compliance
compliance.content:
Right to Access: You can request a copy of all personal data we hold about you.

Right to Rectification: You can request correction of any inaccurate personal data.

Right to Erasure: You can request deletion of your personal data at any time.

Data Portability: You can request your data in a structured, machine-readable format.

Right to Restrict Processing: You can request limitation of how we process your data.

Right to Object: You can object to processing of your personal data for specific purposes.

dataProcessing.title: Data Processing Information
dataProcessing.content:
What Data We Collect: We only collect images you upload for processing and basic account information necessary for service delivery.

Purpose of Processing: Your data is processed solely for AI image enhancement services and improving our technology.

Data Retention: Processed images are automatically deleted after 30 days. You can delete them immediately after processing.

Data Sharing: We never share, sell, or distribute your personal data or images to third parties.

apartmentFitness.title: Small Apartment Fitness Ideas: Stay Fit Without Leaving Home
apartmentFitness.content:
Living in a small apartment doesn't mean you have to sacrifice your fitness goals. With a little creativity and the right approach, you can build strength, improve endurance, and stay healthy—all within the comfort of your home. Whether you're short on space, equipment, or time, these small apartment fitness ideas will help you make the most of what you have.

1. Bodyweight Workouts: No Equipment Needed

When space is limited, your body becomes your best gym tool. Bodyweight exercises are incredibly effective and require zero equipment. Try combining the following moves for a full-body routine:

Squats – Great for legs and glutes.

Push-ups – Strengthens the chest, shoulders, and core.

Planks – Builds core stability.

Lunges – Improves balance and leg strength.

Burpees or mountain climbers – Boosts your heart rate for a quick cardio fix.

💡 Tip: Use a yoga mat to protect your floors and reduce noise for your downstairs neighbors.

2. Compact Home Fitness Equipment

You don't need bulky machines to get results. Invest in small, versatile tools that can easily fit under your bed or in a closet:

Resistance bands – Perfect for strength training and stretching.

Adjustable dumbbells or kettlebells – Add resistance without taking up space.

Jump rope – A quick cardio solution that can be done in short bursts.

Foldable yoga mat or step platform – Great for mobility and low-impact routines.

3. Make Use of Vertical Space

If your floor space is tight, think up. Install a pull-up bar on your door frame, or use wall-mounted hooks for resistance bands and suspension trainers like TRX. This way, you can perform a wide range of exercises without cluttering your apartment.

4. Try Quiet, Low-Impact Workouts

If you're worried about noise, there are plenty of quiet workouts that still burn calories and build muscle:

Yoga or Pilates – Improves flexibility and core strength.

Isometric exercises – Like wall sits or planks, they build endurance silently.

Slow, controlled strength training – Focus on form and muscle tension rather than speed.

5. Use Everyday Items as Weights

Get creative with what you already have at home:

Water bottles or detergent jugs → DIY dumbbells

A sturdy chair → Step-ups or tricep dips

A towel → Resistance for stretches or core twists

You'll be surprised at how effective household fitness can be.

6. Set Up a Mini Workout Zone

Dedicate even a small corner to your workouts. Keeping your mat, resistance bands, and water bottle ready will make it easier to stay consistent. Add a plant or a motivational quote for a personal touch that inspires you to move.

7. Incorporate Movement Into Daily Life

You don't always need a structured workout session. Try adding movement throughout your day:

Do squats while waiting for the microwave.

Stretch during work breaks.

Dance for 10 minutes to your favorite song.

Small movements add up and keep your energy levels high.

8. Follow Online Workouts

Hundreds of free fitness classes are available online—from yoga to HIIT and dance. Find a trainer whose energy you enjoy and follow along. It's like having a personal coach in your living room!

Conclusion

A small apartment doesn't have to limit your fitness potential. With bodyweight exercises, compact equipment, and a little creativity, you can stay active and healthy right where you are. Remember, the key is consistency over perfection—even 15 minutes a day makes a difference.

So clear a little space, roll out your mat, and get moving—your apartment is your gym now.

budgetEquipment.title: Best Budget Equipment for Home Gyms: Build Strength Without Breaking the Bank
budgetEquipment.content:
Creating a home gym doesn't have to drain your savings. With a little planning and a few smart purchases, you can build an effective, space-friendly workout setup that keeps you motivated without spending thousands. Whether you live in a small apartment or simply want affordable options, here's how to get the most out of your money when building a home gym.

0. Start with a Plan

Before buying anything, define your goals. Are you focused on strength training, fat loss, or general fitness? Knowing your priorities helps you avoid wasting money on unnecessary equipment.

Also, think about your available space. If you're setting up in a small room or a corner of your living area, compact or foldable items are your best friends.

1. Resistance Bands

If you're looking for the most budget-friendly and versatile option, resistance bands are unbeatable. They take up almost no space, cost very little, and can be used for everything from stretching to strength training.

You can anchor them to a door, a railing, or even use them with a pull-up bar. They're especially great for beginners and for adding extra resistance to bodyweight workouts.

2. Adjustable Dumbbells

Buying a whole rack of dumbbells can be expensive and take up too much space. Adjustable dumbbells solve both problems.

With a single pair, you can change weights easily and perform dozens of exercises — curls, presses, rows, lunges, and more. While they're pricier than bands, they're a smart long-term investment because they replace an entire set of traditional dumbbells.

3. Kettlebells

Kettlebells are another excellent low-cost, high-impact tool. They're ideal for building strength and endurance through dynamic movements like swings, goblet squats, and presses.

You can start with one moderate weight and expand later if needed. Plus, they're durable — one kettlebell can literally last you a lifetime.

4. A Foldable Bench

Adding a simple foldable bench instantly increases the number of exercises you can do at home. It allows you to perform presses, step-ups, Bulgarian split squats, and even core exercises more comfortably.

Look for a sturdy, adjustable bench that can be stored easily when not in use.

5. Pull-Up Bar or Suspension Trainer

A doorway pull-up bar or a suspension trainer (like TRX) is perfect for upper body and core strength. They take almost no space and can be used for a wide range of exercises — pull-ups, rows, push-ups, and planks with added instability.

They're especially useful if you prefer bodyweight training over weights.

6. Jump Rope

For cardio on a budget, nothing beats a jump rope. It's inexpensive, effective, and burns calories fast.

Even a few minutes of skipping can dramatically improve your coordination and cardiovascular health. Just make sure you have enough ceiling height or take it outside if possible.

7. Use What You Already Have

You don't have to buy everything at once. In fact, many household items can double as gym gear.

Use filled water bottles or detergent jugs as makeshift dumbbells, a sturdy chair for tricep dips, or a towel for resistance stretches. Get creative — what matters most is consistency, not fancy equipment.

Tips to Save More

• Buy second-hand: Check local marketplaces or community groups. Many people sell barely used gym gear for a fraction of the price.

• Wait for sales: Sports stores and online platforms often have big seasonal discounts.

• Prioritize versatility: Equipment that allows multiple exercises is a better investment than single-purpose machines.

• Maintain your gear: Wipe down weights and store them properly to extend their lifespan.

Putting It All Together

If you're just starting out, begin with resistance bands, a jump rope, and perhaps one adjustable dumbbell or kettlebell. As you progress, you can expand your setup with a foldable bench and a pull-up bar.

Even with a modest budget, this combination covers strength, cardio, and flexibility training — all without needing a gym membership.
